questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiac poison
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Belladonna (Deadly Nightshade) contains atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which mainly cause anticholinergic toxicity (dry mouth, mydriasis, tachycardia, delirium) but do not directly affect cardiac contractility like cardiac glycosides Other options: (B) Aconitum napellus: Aconite (Monkshood) contains aconitine, which activates sodium channels, causing ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension, and death (C) Cerbera thevetia: Yellow Oleander contains cardiac glycosides, similar to digitalis, causing bradycardia, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest (D) Digitalis purpurea: Foxglove plant (Digitalis) contains digoxin-like cardiac glycosides, which inhibit Na?/K?-ATPase, leading to increased intracellular calcium and cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A) Nux Vomica ? 3. Strychnine & Brucine causes convulsions by blocking glycine receptor B) Ratti (Abrus precatorius) ? 1. Abrin ? Highly toxic plant protein causing hemorrhagic gastroenteritis C) Dhatura ? 4. Hyoscyamine & Scopolamine ? Causes anticholinergic toxicity (dilated pupils, delirium, tachycardia) D) Opium ? 2. Morphine ? Narcotic analgesic causing respiratory depression

questions.text: Match the following related to eruption of teeth in adults
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Order of eruption A. 1stpermanent teeth to erupt -1st permanent Molars – erupt at 6-years. B. Next to erupt –central incisors –erupt at 7 Yeats C. Lateral incisors erupt at 8 Years D. 1st permanent premolar –erupts at 9 years E. 2nd permanent premolar erupts at 10 years F. Canine erupts at 11 years G. 2nd permanent molar erupts at 12 years H. 3rd permanent molar erupts at 18 years • Whenever permanent molars erupts? total number of teeth increase known as super added permanent teeth. • 1st 5 permanent teeth inside the canine termed as successional permanent teeth

choices.text: Cadaveric spasm with mud in the hands

questions.text: Child presents to casualty with froth from oral cavity which reappears on wiping. All of the following may be seen during autopsy except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The child presenting with frothing from the mouth that reappears on wiping strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death D) Arsenic in hair root is not a feature of drowning. This is a sign of chronic arsenic poisoning, which is unrelated to drowning Other options: A) Ballooning of lungs: Seen due to aspiration of water, leading to overdistended, edematous lungs B) Cadaveric spasm with mud in the hands: Seen in freshwater drowning, where the victim clutches mud or weeds in a panic C) Paltauf hemorrhages: Subpleural hemorrhages in the lungs due to increased intrathoracic pressure during drowning

questions.text: Tattooing in case of firearm entry is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tattooing (stippling) around a firearm entry wound is caused by unburnt gunpowder particles that embed into the skin Other options: A) Soot particles – Cause smudging/blackening (not tattooing), seen in close-range wounds C) Muzzle imprint – Occurs in contact gunshot wounds when the muzzle burns and presses against the skin D) Flame – Causes burns and charring, not tattooing

questions.text: A patient with history of previous abdominal surgery presents to casualty with fever and abdominal pain. X ray abdomen was taken with the findings shown in the given image. These finding correspond to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The presence of surgical scissors in the abdominal cavity following previous surgery is an example of gross medical negligence, where the negligence is so obvious that no further proof is required Res ipsa loquitur – "The thing speaks for itself" • Applied when negligence is so evident that it does not require further proof • Example: Retained foreign body (e.g., scissors, gauze) after surgery Other options: B) Res judicata: The matter has been judged. A case that has already been decided by a court and cannot be re-litigated C) Novus actus interveniens: New intervening act. A new act that breaks the chain of causation in a legal case D) Vicarious liability: Employer liability for employee’s negligence. A hospital or senior doctor can be held responsible for negligence by a subordinate

questions.text: Identify the injury in the given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A contusion (bruise) is caused by blunt force trauma leading to extravasation of blood into soft tissues without a break in the skin Key Features of Contusion: • Skin may appear red, blue, purple, or yellowish due to breakdown of hemoglobin • No skin breach is present • Swelling and tenderness may be seen • Occurs due to blunt force trauma (e.g., punches, falls) Other Options: Laceration: A tear in the skin with irregular margins caused by blunt trauma Abrasion: Superficial injury due to friction or scraping of the skin Incised wound: A clean, sharp-edged wound caused by a sharp object (e.g., knife)

questions.text: Spanish windlass technique, a type of mechanical asphyxia is also known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Spanish Windlass technique is a form of mechanical asphyxia in which a cord or ligature is tightened around the neck using a twisting mechanism, such as a stick or rod. This method was historically used for execution and homicide Garrotting: A method of strangulation where a ligature is tightened using a twisting motion Other options: A) Strangulation – General term for external compression of the neck, can include manual, ligature, or hanging C) Throttling – Manual strangulation using hands, fingers, or forearm D) Mugging – Violent attack or robbery, often involving force but not necessarily strangulation

questions.text: A 76-year-old lady presents to emergency department with increasing somnolence and lethargy for one day. Her symptoms are associated with headache, mild nausea but no vomiting. There was a history of fall in washroom. A head CT without contrast demonstrates a crescent shaped hyperdensity that crosses suture lines. She dies after 4 days. Autopsy findings are given below. What could be the possible diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Subdural Hematoma (SDH): Crescent-shaped hyperdensity, crosses suture lines, due to rupture of bridging veins Other options: A) Epidural Hematoma (EDH): Typically biconvex (lentiform) hyperdensity on CT, does not cross suture lines, often associated with middle meningeal artery rupture C) Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH); Presents with sudden thunderclap headache, usually from aneurysmal rupture, with blood in the basal cisterns on CT D) Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH): Shows focal hyperdensity within brain parenchyma, not crescent-shaped bleeding

questions.text: Most common cause of SDH bleed is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Subdural Hematoma (SDH) occurs due to the tearing of bridging veins, which connect the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses. These veins are particularly vulnerable in elderly individuals and alcoholics, where brain atrophy increases tension on the veins. Trauma (e.g., fall, head injury) is the most common cause Other options: A) Rupture of Middle Meningeal Artery: Causes epidural hematoma (EDH), which appears biconvex (lentiform) on CT and does not cross suture lines C) Rupture of Berry Aneurysm: Causes subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), presenting as a thunderclap headache, not subdural bleeding D) Rupture of Middle Cerebral Artery: Leads to intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) or ischemic stroke, not SDH

questions.text: A scorpion sting case comes to casualty with features of pain, hypotension and basal crepts in lungs. Treatment of choice in this case is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Scorpion venom causes autonomic storm, leading to massive catecholamine release (both ? and ? effects). This results in hypertension followed by hypotension, pulmonary edema, and cardiac toxicity. Prazosin (?-1 blocker) is the treatment of choice as it reverses vasoconstriction and reduces afterload, improving blood flow and preventing pulmonary edema Other options: B) Furosemide: Not used because pulmonary edema in scorpion sting is due to vasoconstriction, not fluid overload C) Dopamine: May worsen symptoms by increasing cardiac workload and worsening pulmonary edema D) None of the above: Incorrect, as Prazosin is the best treatment

questions.text: A 45 year old female with history of alcoholism for about 10 years develops liver cirrhosis. Now she suddenly leaves alcohol and within 2-3 days presents to casualty with withdrawal symptoms and in unconscious state. Preferred treatment of choice is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lorazepam This patient is experiencing alcohol withdrawal delirium (delirium tremens, DT), which presents 2–3 days after stopping alcohol and is characterized by • Severe autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, sweating) • Tremors, seizures, hallucinations, and agitation • Altered mental status or unconsciousness in severe cases Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment Lorazepam is preferred because • Shorter half-life & intermediate duration, making it safer in liver disease (cirrhosis) • Metabolized via glucuronidation, not affected by impaired hepatic function • Effective in preventing seizures & controlling withdrawal symptoms Other options: A) Diazepam: Long-acting, metabolized in the liver (CYP450); not preferred in liver failure B) Alprazolam: Short-acting, not effective for severe withdrawal D) Clonazepam: Long-acting, but less commonly used for alcohol withdrawal

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dipsomania ? Uncontrollable craving for alcohol Kleptomania ? Impulse to steal unnecessary items Pyromania ? Compulsive desire to set fires Mutilomania ? Impulse to harm/mutilate animals or oneself

questions.text: Identify the findings given in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marbling: Decomposition-related pattern due to bacterial action on blood vessels, creating a greenish-black network (because of sulfhemoglobin) seen 36-48 hours of death Other options: Lividity (Livor Mortis): Postmortem pooling of blood in dependent areas, appearing as purplish discoloration Tattooing: Blackened or stippled marks due to unburnt gunpowder in firearm injuries Ecchymosis: A bruise caused by blood leakage under the skin due to trauma

questions.text: In a dead born fetus gas was noted in the aorta during USG of mother. True about this is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Robert’s Sign: • Presence of gas in the great vessels (e.g., aorta, heart, and other large vessels) of a dead fetus, seen on ultrasound • Appears 12 hours to 1 week after intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) • Most specific sign of fetal death Other options: Spalding Sign: Overlapping of fetal skull bones due to liquefaction of brain tissue. It occurs one week or more after IUFD Ball Sign describes a rounded shape of the fetus in severe oligohydramnios (decreased amniotic fluid) Deuel’s Halo Sign: Halo-like fluid collection around the skull due to subcutaneous edema in IUFD

questions.text: Most common cause of death due to drowning in cold water is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vagal Inhibition: • Cold shock response triggers excessive vagal stimulation • Leads to bradycardia, cardiac arrest, and sudden death even before water enters the lungs • Most common cause of immediate death in cold water drowning Other options: Asphyxia (A): Common in drowning due to airway obstruction by water. However, in cold water drowning, vagal inhibition occurs before full asphyxiation, leading to sudden death Laryngospasm (C): Reflex closure of the vocal cords, preventing water entry. It can contribute to dry drowning, but not the most common cause of death in cold water drowning Ventricular Fibrillation (D): Possible in prolonged hypothermia due to electrical instability of the heart. More common in prolonged cold exposure rather than immediate drowning events

questions.text: The following are the laws related to insanity A. Durhams rule B. Currens rule C. Murphys rule D. Ashleys rule
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Durham's Rule (A): States that a defendant is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act was the product of mental illness. Also known as the "Product Test", it was established in Durham v. United States (1954) Curren’s Rule (B): A modification of the Durham Rule, adding that the individual must lack substantial capacity to appreciate the criminality of their conduct or conform their conduct to the law Murphy’s Rule (C): No known law related to insanity under this name Ashley Rule (D): No recognized legal doctrine under this name

questions.text: Cry of fetus was heard by the doctor before the delivery of the head. What is true about this statement.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vagitus uterinus refers to the crying of the fetus while still inside the uterus, typically before the head is delivered. This can happen when the amniotic sac has ruptured, and air enters the uterus, allowing the fetus to take a breath and produce a cry. It is a rare occurrence and is sometimes observed during C-sections or breech deliveries Other Options: B) Infection of vagina: Not related to fetal crying C) Infection of uterus: Can cause complications but does not cause fetal crying D) Infection of vagina and uterus: Not relevant to this situation

questions.text: What is correct regarding the protocol of management of snake bite. (Multiple answers) A. Kill the snake B. ASV administration after admission C. Immobilization D. Debridement of wound E. Apply tourniquet F. Wash the wound
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Asv administration if signs of systemic inhibition – toxicity & poisoning symptoms Immobilization- systemic absorption of poison is prevented by Immobilization Debridement & torniquet application not recommended- as pressure is not controllable. Wash with plain water is recommended, not soap washing.

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is due to consumption of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hooch tragedy refers to mass poisoning due to the consumption of adulterated or illicitly brewed alcohol. Methanol (methyl alcohol) is the primary toxic component responsible for these poisonings It is sometimes added to illicit liquor to increase potency, but its metabolism leads to the formation of formaldehyde and formic acid, causing blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death Other Options: A) Ethanol: not responsible for hooch tragedies C) Ethylene glycol: Found in antifreeze, but not commonly involved in hooch tragedies D) Ethyl oxide: Not relevant to illicit alcohol poisoning

questions.text: A person working in matchbox industry, presents with multiple discharging sinuses of jaw. What could be the most likely poisoning
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A person working in the matchbox industry is at risk of phosphorus poisoning, particularly white phosphorus, which was historically used in matchstick production Chronic exposure to white phosphorus can lead to "Phossy Jaw" (phosphorus necrosis of the jaw), characterized by • Multiple discharging sinuses • Severe jawbone destruction (osteonecrosis) • Facial swelling and pain Other Options: A) Lead: Can cause lead poisoning with symptoms like anemia, abdominal pain, and neuropathy but does not lead to jaw necrosis C) Arsenic: Causes skin lesions, peripheral neuropathy, and cancer but not phossy jaw D) Cadmium: Associated with Itai-Itai disease (osteomalacia and renal damage) but not jaw necrosis

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ligature strangulation: • Horizontal or Oblique Ligature Mark: Unlike hanging, where the ligature mark is typically oblique and rises upward, in ligature strangulation, it is usually horizontal or nearly horizontal around the neck • Multiple Constriction Marks: The presence of deep constriction marks with possible abrasions or bruising suggests forceful application of a ligature • Petechial Hemorrhages: Commonly seen in the conjunctivae and face due to vascular congestion and venous obstruction • Soft Tissue Injuries: May show subcutaneous hemorrhage, muscle bruising, and fractures of the hyoid bone due to external pressure Other Options: B) Hanging: Ligature mark is typically oblique, incomplete, and high up in the neck with no or minimal bruising C) Throttling: Finger marks, nail scratches, and extensive bruising on the neck due to manual strangulation D) Smothering: No characteristic neck findings; obstruction of mouth/nose with suffocation signs

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Key features of incised looking lacerated wound: • Irregular Edges with Tissue Bridging • Commonly Seen Over Bony Prominences • Caused by Blunt Force Trauma Other Options: B) Incised Wound: True incised wounds have sharp, well-defined edges without tissue bridging C) Stab Wound: A stab wound is deeper than it is wide, with clean-cut edges from a penetrating object D) Abrasion: Abrasions involve superficial skin loss due to friction, with no deep tissue involvement

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1 Frotteurism: Rubbing against private parts Eonism: Wearing clothes of opposite gender Necrophilia: Sexual intercourse with a dead body Exhibitionism: Display of private parts

questions.text: ‘A’ kills ‘B’ with a knife. Another person ‘Z’ saw ‘A’ with knife in the park few minutes before murder. ‘Z’ give this statement in court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Indirect Evidence (Circumstantial Evidence) (Option B) refers to evidence that suggests involvement in a crime without directly proving it. Seeing A with a knife before the murder is circumstantial evidence that could imply involvement but does not directly establish guilt Other options: Direct Evidence (Option A) would be if Z saw A stabbing B. However, Z only saw A with a knife before the murder, not the act itself Hostile Evidence (Option C) applies when a witness turns hostile (i.e., changes their statement to favor the accused) Hearsay Evidence (Option D) refers to information given by a witness that they heard from someone else rather than personally witnessing

questions.text: Finger prints appears first at what gestational age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fingerprint formation begins at around 10 weeks of gestation and becomes well-defined by 12-16 weeks. The dermal ridges (which form the basis of fingerprints) start developing in the fetal epidermis during this period. These patterns remain unchanged throughout life and are unique to each individual Other Options: A) 28-30 weeks ? By this time, fingerprints are already fully developed C) 24-28 weeks ? Fingerprints are already present before this period D) 32-36 weeks ? Much later than the actual fingerprint formation timeline.

questions.text: Identify the mechanical injury shown in the picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hesitational cuts (also known as tentative cuts) are multiple, superficial, parallel cuts often seen in cases of self-inflicted injuries. They are shallow and irregular, commonly found on wrists, neck, or forearms in individuals attempting suicide. These cuts indicate indecisiveness before making a deep, fatal incision Other Options: A) Grazed abrasion ? A superficial skin injury caused by friction, like sliding on rough surfaces C) Six penny bruise ? A circular or coin-shaped bruise, often seen in blunt force trauma D) Patterned abrasion ? Abrasion that takes the shape of the object causing the injury, e.g., a tire mark or shoe sole imprint

questions.text: Which test is done to identify presence of vaginal cells on penis in an accused of rape?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lugol’s iodine test is used to detect vaginal epithelial cells on the penis of an accused in cases of sexual assault or rape. Vaginal cells contain glycogen, which reacts with iodine, staining them brown or mahogany. It helps confirm recent sexual contact Other Options: A) Precipitin test: Used to differentiate between human and animal blood B) Florence test: Used to detect choline in semen, confirming the presence of seminal fluid D) Toluidine blue test: Used in rape victims to detect microscopic genital injuries, not for identifying vaginal cells on the accused

questions.text: Identify the plant having yellow flowers where seeds are present in prickly capsules?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Causes epidenmic dropsy. Argemone mexicana (Mexican poppy) has yellow flowers and prickly seed capsules It is a toxic plant and its seeds resemble mustard seeds, leading to epidemic dropsy when adulterated in food oil. Other Options: B) Nerium odorum (Oleander): Has pink/white flowers, not yellow C) Papaver somniferum (Opium poppy): Has white/lavender flowers, and the capsules are smooth, not prickly D) Calotropis: Has purple/white flowers, not yellow

questions.text: Symptom seen in chronic arsenic poisoning are ? 1) Aldrich- Mee’s lines on nails 2) Rain drop pigmentation 3) Mixed neuropathy 4) Luminescent vomit 5) Bone marrow depression
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Luminescent vomit ? Seen in phosphorus poisoning 1) Aldrich-Mees lines on nails: White transverse lines on nails 2) Rain-drop pigmentation: Hyperpigmented and hypopigmented skin spots, giving a "raindrop" appearance 3) Mixed neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy with both motor and sensory involvement 5) Bone marrow depression: Leads to pancytopenia and anemia

questions.text: Treatment of acute arsenic poisoning is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dimercaprol ? First-line chelating agent for arsenic poisoning. It binds arsenic and facilitates its excretion Other options: A) Dialysed iron ? Not used in arsenic poisoning; used in iron toxicity B) Calcium EDTA ? Used for lead poisoning, not arsenic D) Desferrioxamine ? Used for iron poisoning, not arsenic

questions.text: The manifestations of organo-phosphorus poisoning are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Organophosphorus (OP) poisoning leads to excessive cholinergic activity due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition, causing an accumulation of acetylcholine. This results in muscarinic, nicotinic, and CNS effects Miosis (pupil constriction) is a hallmark of OP poisoning due to excessive parasympathetic stimulation. Mydriasis (pupil dilation) occurs in atropine poisoning or sympathetic activation, not OP poisoning Classic Features of OP Poisoning (DUMBBELSS): • D ? Diarrhea (NOT diuresis, but urinary incontinence can occur) • U ? Urination (frequent urination due to bladder contraction) • M ? Miosis (NOT mydriasis) • B ? Bronchospasm / Bronchorrhea • B ? Bradycardia (excess parasympathetic stimulation) • E ? Emesis • L ? Lacrimation • S ? Salivation • S ? Sweating

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hand and feet

questions.text: Which of the following is not the feature of cocaine intoxication?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cocaine is a stimulant that increases dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin levels, leading to sympathetic overactivity (adrenergic stimulation) Cocaine causes mydriasis (dilated pupils) and tachycardia, not bradycardia Other options: A) Tingling and numbness of hands and feet due to vasoconstriction and local anesthetic effects of cocaine C) Hypertension due to increased sympathetic activity (?-adrenergic stimulation) D) Hyperthermia due to increased muscle activity and vasoconstriction, leading to impaired heat dissipation

questions.text: A patient comes to emergency with salivation , diarrhea, watery eyes & dysuria. What will be the first line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The patient's symptoms (salivation, diarrhea, watery eyes, dysuria) suggest cholinergic toxicity, most likely due to organophosphate poisoning (commonly found in pesticides). Organophosphates inhibit acetylcholinesterase, leading to excessive acetylcholine (ACh) at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors Atropine (first-line treatment) • A muscarinic antagonist that blocks excess ACh at muscarinic receptors • Rapidly reverses symptoms like bronchorrhea, bradycardia, and hypotension • Given IV in high doses until secretions dry up Other Options: A) Calcium gluconate used for hyperkalemia, calcium channel blocker toxicity, or hydrofluoric acid poisoning; NOT for organophosphate poisoning B) Pralidoxime (2-PAM) helps regenerate acetylcholinesterase but is given after atropine, not as a first-line drug D) Obidoxime similar to pralidoxime, used as an acetylcholinesterase reactivator, but not the first-line treatment

questions.text: Which poisoning will predominantly lead to hypertension?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cocaine blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, leading to excessive sympathetic stimulation. This results in • Hypertension • Tachycardia • Hyperthermia • Mydriasis (dilated pupils) Other Options: B) Acute Alcohol Intoxication usually causes hypotension due to vasodilation C) Some Antidepressants (e.g., TCAs, SSRIs, MAOIs): TCAs can cause hypotension (alpha-blocking effect), but MAOIs can lead to hypertensive crisis, especially with tyramine-containing foods D) Organophosphorus Poisoning causes bradycardia, bronchoconstriction, and hypotension due to cholinergic excess

questions.text: Two friends after consuming alcohol, fought over a common girlfriend. One of them pushed the other on the floor and sat on his chest and closed his mouth and nostrils with his hand. This form of causing death is called as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Burking is a form of mechanical asphyxia where the victim is smothered (by closing the mouth and nostrils) while simultaneously applying pressure on the chest to prevent respiratory movements. It is named after the Burke and Hare murders (1828), where victims were killed by this method to provide fresh bodies for anatomical dissection Other Options: A) Smothering: Involves blocking the nose and mouth alone, but without chest compression C) Overlaying: Occurs when an adult accidentally rolls over an infant, causing asphyxia (common in co-sleeping) D) Suffocation: A broad term encompassing any process that prevents breathing, including smothering, choking, or strangulation

choices.text: Compression on Rt internal Jugular vein

questions.text: A body comes for autopsy with ligature mark on 1/3rd of the neck. On examination Rt eye is open left eye is closed with saliva dribbling from Rt angle of mouth. The cause of Rt side eye remaining open is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In hanging, the position of the ligature mark determines the structures compressed. In this case, the ligature mark is at the upper 1/3rd of the neck, which can compress the cervical sympathetic chain on one side, leading to unilateral autonomic dysfunction. Why is the right eye open? • The cervical sympathetic chain controls the levator palpebrae superioris (via sympathetic fibers) • Compression on one side (right) causes ipsilateral ptosis, making the left eye closed while the right remains open • This is a sign of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis), although partial effects are seen in strangulation or hanging cases Other Options: A) Compression of right carotid artery ? Would lead to cerebral ischemia but does not explain eye asymmetry B) Compression of right IJV ? Leads to venous congestion, causing petechiae and cyanosis, but does not affect eyelid opening C) Compression of right vagus nerve ? Causes bradycardia and cardiac arrest but does not influence eyelid movement

choices.text: Air pressure changes due to blast
Collapse of building due to blast

questions.text: A person is brought dead to casualty following an explosion. Multiple abrasions and lacerations are seen over his right chest region near nipple and left upper abdomen. These injuries are most likely due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In blast injuries, multiple factors contribute to trauma. The presence of multiple abrasions and lacerations localized to specific areas (right chest and left upper abdomen) suggests penetrating injuries caused by high-velocity projectiles or debris—also known as secondary blast injuries Other Options: B) Explosion burns ? Would present as thermal injuries (charred skin, singed hair, soot deposits), which are not mentioned C) Air pressure changes due to blast ? Causes internal barotrauma (lung contusions, ruptured eardrums), but does not explain external abrasions/lacerations D) Collapse of building due to blast ? Would cause crush injuries and fractures, which are not described

choices.text: Soft tissue crushed between hitting weapon and bone

questions.text: A patient is brought to OPD with injuries. A lacerated wound 3cmX 1cm X bone deep is noted on the scalp. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of the injury?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A lacerated wound on the scalp that is bone deep suggests that the injury is caused by blunt force trauma. In such cases, the skin and soft tissues are crushed between the impacting object and the underlying bone, leading to a tear in the skin with irregular margins. Mechanism of Laceration Formation: When a blunt object (such as a stick, rod, or stone) strikes the scalp, the skin is compressed against the skull. The force overcomes the elasticity of the skin, leading to splitting of the skin and underlying tissues. The wound appears irregular, with bruising and tissue bridges inside Other Options: B) Overstretching forces: More relevant for avulsion injuries, where the skin is forcibly stretched and torn away (e.g., degloving injuries) C) Shearing forces: More common in incised wounds caused by sharp weapons like knives, where the tissue is cut rather than crushed D) Hitting by semi-sharp objects: Would produce an incised-looking lacerated wound, but the given description only mentions laceration, suggesting a purely blunt injury

questions.text: A person comes to OPD with injury to right thigh. O/E a soddened burn injury is noted along with erythema, blisters and line of demarcation which extends down the limb. Most likely cause ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The presence of erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation extending down the limb suggests a scald injury caused by moist heat (e.g., hot liquids, steam) Key Features of Moist Burns (Scald Burns): • Blisters (Bullae) – Due to superficial and partial-thickness skin damage • Line of Demarcation – Often seen in scald burns, where the hot liquid flows down due to gravity • Erythema – Sign of epidermal damage caused by thermal injury Other Options: A) Chemical Burn: Typically presents with necrosis, discoloration, and no clear line of demarcation C) Dry Heat Burn: More commonly causes charring and deep tissue destruction without a fluid-like spread pattern D) Electrical Burn: Often involves deep tissue damage, entry and exit wounds, and can cause muscle necrosis and compartment syndrome

questions.text: A pelvis is brought for forensic examination. What characteristics will identify it as male pelvis? 1. Large obturator foramen 2. Large acetabulum 3. Large sacro-illiac joint surface 4. V- shaped sub-pubic angle 5. Prominent pre-auricular sulcus 6. Everted Ischial tuberosity 7. Wide and shallow greater sciatic notch
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Male pelvis –almost everything bigger, larger, more prominent Except preauricular sulcus –more prominent in a female B. Large Sacroiliac surface means pelvis is wider → female pelvis. C. V shaped subpubic angle → narrow → male pelvis D. U shaped – wider Subpubic angle → wider outlet → female pelvis. E. Everted ischial tuberosity –outlet increased – female pelvis. F. Wide & shallow sciatic notch – female pelvis.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4, E-5 - Incomplete atrophy of the ridges in Dermatitis - Distance between the ridges is changed but the pattern is not altered in infantile paralysis , rickets and acromegaly. - Permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy , electric injury and after exposure to radiation. - Ridge alteration occurs in eczema , Acanthosis Nigricans, scleroderma and dry or Atrophic skin -Moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease.

questions.text: A person working in dye industry presents with nausea, vomiting, conjunctivitis(?), dark bloody stools with pain in throat/mouth and abdomen. What is the most likely poisoning?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A person working in the dye industry presenting with nausea, vomiting, conjunctivitis, dark bloody stools, throat pain, and abdominal pain is most likely suffering from arsenic poisoning Other options: Lead acetate (B) ? Causes chronic toxicity with anemia, neuropathy, and abdominal colic, not acute GI hemorrhage Thallium (C) ? Causes severe neuropathy, alopecia, and painful paresthesias, not dark stools Potassium Permanganate (D) ? Causes severe corrosive injury to the GI tract, but not systemic toxicity like arsenic

questions.text: Organo-phosphorus compounds act by inhibiting Ach-esterase enzyme by which mechanism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Organophosphorus (OP) compounds irreversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase (AChE) by phosphorylating the enzyme’s active site. This leads to accumulation of acetylcholine (ACh) at synapses, resulting in cholinergic toxicity (SLUDGE symptoms: salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, GI upset, and emesis) Other options: A) Competitive inhibition: The inhibitor competes with ACh but does not form a covalent bond. OP compounds irreversibly phosphorylate AChE, making this incorrect C) Non-competitive inhibition: Would bind to a site other than the active site, but OP compounds directly phosphorylate the active site D) Allosteric inhibition: OP compounds do not bind to an allosteric site, but rather directly block AChE activity

questions.text: Which of the following feature is associated with korsakoff’s psychosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic amnestic syndrome associated with thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics Key Features of Korsakoff Psychosis: • Severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) • Retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories) • Confabulation (fabrication of false memories) • Lack of insight • Apathy Other options: A) Global confusion ? Seen in Wernicke encephalopathy, not specifically in Korsakoff psychosis B) Ataxia ? Feature of Wernicke encephalopathy, not a primary symptom of Korsakoff psychosis D) Peripheral neuropathy ? Can occur due to thiamine deficiency but is not a defining feature of Korsakoff psychosis

choices.text: To do a complete physical examination
To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
To call local social worker for help

questions.text: A 16-years-old girl comes to a doctor with fractured forearm. She told she tripped and fell but cigarette burns were observed on her forearm. What will be your next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In cases where abuse is suspected, the first step is always to conduct a thorough physical examination to gather objective evidence before taking further action. This ensures proper documentation of all injuries, patterns, and any other signs of abuse Other options: A) Inform higher authorities ? Reporting is essential after confirming abuse, but it should follow a proper evaluation and documentation C) Discuss with a colleague ? Sharing patient information without assessment breaches confidentiality and is not an immediate step D) Call a social worker ? Social workers should be involved after confirmation of abuse, not before proper evaluation

choices.text: Opinion of a doctor in court

questions.text: First-hand knowledge” refers to-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) First-hand knowledge refers to direct or personal knowledge of an event. A common witness is someone who has personally seen, heard, or experienced the event in question, making their testimony first-hand evidence Other options: A) Opinion of a doctor in court ? This is expert opinion, not first-hand knowledge B) Handwriting expert ? This is also expert evidence, based on analysis, not direct observation D) Fingerprint expert ? Like handwriting experts, they analyze evidence rather than having direct knowledge

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the given image-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aconite (Aconitum napellus), also known as monkshood or wolfsbane, contains aconitine, a potent neurotoxin and cardiotoxin Effects of Aconite Poisoning: • Causes arrhythmias, including AV block, ventricular fibrillation, and bradycardia • Tingling and numbness of the mouth and limbs occur early, followed by severe cardiovascular collapse • There is no specific antidote, but supportive care with antiarrhythmic drugs like lidocaine is used (Neostigmine is NOT an antidote) • All parts of the plant, including the leaves and flowers, are poisonous, not just the root • First symptoms are usually tingling, paresthesia, and nausea, not a sweet taste

questions.text: Match the following columns-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Heroin is commonly referred to as "brown sugar" in illicit drug trade Spanish fly (Cantharidin) is obtained from the blister beetle and is a potent irritant Abrus precatorius (Rosary pea) contains abrin, a highly toxic substance, and is known as Gunchi in India Aconite (Aconitum napellus), also called Blue Rocket, contains aconitine, which is a deadly cardiac poison

Postmortem lividity (settling of blood in dependent parts) Mummification ? Dehydration and preservation of body in dry conditions Marbling ? Greenish-black vein-like pattern due to putrefaction

questions.text: Poisoning by which of these element causes blind staggers alkali disease in livestock?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Selenium toxicity in livestock, also known as "Blind Staggers" or "Alkali Disease," occurs due to excessive selenium intake from plants grown in selenium-rich soil. It leads to symptoms like • Blindness, staggering gait, and weakness • Hoof deformities and hair loss • Respiratory distress and death in severe cases

choices.text: Hospital administration is responsible for the actions of interns and trainees
A nurse assisting a surgery is a borrowed servant of the hospital
Doctor assisting a surgeon for fee in OT
Physician is responsible for the acts of the orderlies and nursing staff done by his orders

questions.text: All are true about Doctrine of borrowed servant except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The "Doctrine of Borrowed Servant" states that an employer (e.g., hospital administration) is not liable for an employee's actions if the employee was temporarily under the direct control of another superior (e.g., a doctor) A nurse assisting in surgery is not a "borrowed servant" but an employee of the hospital, acting under hospital policies rather than the direct control of the surgeon Other options: A) Hospital administration is responsible for actions of interns and trainees because they are employed and supervised by the hospital C) A doctor assisting a surgeon for a fee is acting independently and could be considered a borrowed servant under the control of the surgeon D) A physician is responsible for acts performed by orderlies and nursing staff when following his direct instructions

questions.text: Calculate the Age of fetus having CRL 23 cm, foot length 7 cm. Talus is present and testes are present at superficial inguinal ring?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: All are the features present in male skull as compared to female skull except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Male skulls are generally more robust and have larger teeth, foramen magnum, and frontal sinuses due to overall skeletal mass and development Female skulls tend to have more prominent parietal eminences, contributing to a rounder and smoother cranial shape

questions.text: All of the following are features of female skull except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Heavy cheek bones • Features of a female skull typically include: • Narrow mastoid tip: Females generally have a smaller, more pointed mastoid process compared to males, whose mastoid processes are larger and more blunt. • Prominent frontal and parietal bones: The frontal bone in females is often more rounded, and the parietal bones are more prominent, contributing to a smoother contour of the skull. • Round orbits: Female skulls typically have rounder eye sockets with sharp upper borders, whereas male skulls have squarer orbits with blunter upper margins. • Light and less pronounced cheekbones: Contrary to the option "heavy cheek bones," female skulls usually have less pronounced zygomatic arches (cheekbones) compared to males, whose cheekbones are more prominent and robust.

questions.text: Most common route of absorbtion of lead in case of inorganic lead poisoning is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In cases of inorganic lead poisoning, inhalation is the most common route of absorption, especially in occupational exposure (e.g., battery workers, painters, smelters). Fine lead dust and fumes are absorbed directly through the lungs, leading to high bioavailability Other Options: B) Ingestion from contaminated hands ? Significant in non-industrial exposure, but not the primary route in occupational settings C) Food contamination ? Can occur but is not the most common route D) Skin absorption ? Inorganic lead is poorly absorbed through intact skin (unlike organic lead, which can penetrate skin)

questions.text: Barberio’s test detects
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Barberio's test is a chemical test used to detect spermine, which is a polyamine found in semen. This test is used in forensic medicine to confirm the presence of semen in biological samples. Other Options: B) Choline ? Detected by the Florence test, not Barberio's C) Fructose acid phosphatase ? Related to prostatic secretions, not spermine D) Creatine kinase ? A muscle enzyme, not related to semen detection.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of death in salt water drowning except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hemodilution (D) occurs in freshwater drowning, where hypotonic water enters the circulation, diluting blood In saltwater drowning, the hypertonic seawater causes fluid shifts due to osmosis, leading to Hemoconcentration ? Water moves from blood plasma into alveoli, increasing blood viscosity Hypernatremia ? Due to the high salt concentration in seawater Cardiac anoxia ? Hypoxia due to pulmonary edema and respiratory failure

questions.text: A murder suspect was under the police custody. He was put in prone position on a flat surface and his wrist and ankles were tied over the surface. What is this type of torture called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hog tying is a type of positional asphyxia where a person's wrists and ankles are tied together behind their back while they are in a prone position. This position restricts chest expansion, leading to respiratory distress and possible death due to asphyxia. Other options: Arm bar: A type of joint lock used in martial arts, not a method of torture Chepuwa: place a wooden rod between thighs, tightly tie those thighs together because of which that rod will press against bone resulting in extreme pain Parrot perch: A method where a person is suspended with hands and feet tied to a bar, often leading to nerve damage

questions.text: Match the following postmortem changes with the time of their appearances
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A) Marbling ? 2-3 days B) Adipocere ? > 3 weeks C) Sphincter relaxation ? within 24 hours D) Tissue liquefaction ? 5-10 days Marbling occurs early due to bacterial activity in the veins, in 2-3 days Adipocere forms after several weeks, especially in moist conditions Sphincter relaxation is typically seen within 24 hours Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition that happens around 5-10 days after death

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Filigree burns, also known as arborescent burns or lightning burns, occur due to the passage of high-voltage electricity or lightning strikes. They appear as branching, fern-like reddish patterns on the skin due to capillary rupture. These burns are typically painless and transient, fading within hours to days Other options: Postmortem lividity (B): Also known as livor mortis, it is the purplish discoloration of dependent body parts due to blood settling after death Marbling (C): A greenish-black discoloration along veins in decomposing bodies due to bacterial gas formation

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has been brought to casualty department by her parents with an alleged history of sexual assault by a 22-year-old male. Parents refused for medical examination. What should be the doctor do in such situation? 1. Start treatment for STD and Pregnancy 2. Inform the police 3. Record refusal of consent 4. Take vaginal sample 5. Start medical examination
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In cases of alleged sexual assault involving a minor, consent for medical examination is required from the legal guardian, but in cases of sexual assault, the doctor must report to the police regardless of parental consent, as mandated by law (POCSO Act). While it is crucial to inform the police and document the refusal of consent to be done Other options: Starting treatment for STDs, pregnancy, or collecting vaginal samples, start medical examination without consent is incorrect, as these actions require explicit permission unless there is an overriding legal obligation to proceed

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marbling (B): The greenish-black pattern of veins visible in decomposing bodies caused by bacterial growth and gas production Other options: Postmortem lividity (A): A reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to blood settling in dependent areas after death Filigree burns (C): A branching burn pattern, typically seen in lightning strikes, caused by superficial capillary rupture

questions.text: Cause of death in freshwater drowning could be 1. Dilutional hyponatremia 2. Hemodilution 3. Decrease in K+ 4. Disruption of pulmonary surfactant 5. Arrythmiauld be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In freshwater drowning, the primary cause of increased potassium levels is hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells). When freshwater enters the lungs and is absorbed into the bloodstream, it causes hemolysis due to the dilution of blood and disruption of cell membranes. This releases potassium from the cells into the bloodstream, leading to hyperkalemia (increased potassium levels), which can cause serious cardiac arrhythmias and contribute to death Dilutional hyponatremia: The absorption of a large volume of freshwater into the bloodstream can dilute the sodium levels, causing hyponatremia, which can lead to brain swelling and death Hemodilution: The influx of freshwater into the body can lead to a decrease in blood osmolality, causing dilution of blood components, including red blood cells Disruption of pulmonary surfactant: The inhalation of water can disrupt the function of pulmonary surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, and respiratory failure Arrhythmia: The electrolyte disturbances and stress on the body from drowning can lead to fatal arrhythmias, especially due to hypoxia and electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: Match the following columns
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A) Lathi ? 4. Tram line bruise B) RTA (Road Traffic Accident) ? 1. Grazed abrasion C) Blade ? 2. Incised wound D) Axe ? 3. Chop wound Lathi (stick) typically causes tram line bruises, which are parallel bruises from the impact RTA injuries often result in grazed abrasions, especially from the contact with the road surface A blade (like a knife) causes incised wounds, which are clean, sharp cuts An axe causes chop wounds, which are deep, severe cuts with tissue loss

questions.text: Medial end of the clavicle is fused; all the parts of the body of the sternum are fused. The age of the individual is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) > 25 years The medial end of the clavicle fuses around the age of 25 years, and the fusion of all parts of the body of the sternum also typically occurs after 22-25 years. Therefore, the correct answer is D) >25 years

questions.text: Match the following columns
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A-4 B-1 C-2 D-3 A) Quinine ? 4. Abortifacient B) Chloral hydrate ? 1. Stupefying agent C) Zinc chloride ? 2. Irritant D) Potassium carbonate ? 3. Corrosive Quinine is known to cause uterine contractions and has been used historically as an abortifacient Chloral hydrate is a sedative, often used as a stupefying agent Zinc chloride can cause irritation to the gastrointestinal tract, making it an irritant Potassium carbonate is a strong corrosive substance, capable of damaging tissues

questions.text: What is the cause of this condition shown in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A shotgun injury causes distinctive patterns due to the spread of multiple pellets from the shotgun shell. The pellets create a larger, irregular wound with characteristic pellet marks on the skin around the wound, often producing a spread or circular pattern. This is a typical feature of shotgun injuries Other options: Rifled firearm causes a more focused and single-point entry wound Powder tattooing is caused by the discharge of a firearm from close range, leading to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin Heated ice pick causes a stab wound with thermal injury but lacks the spread pattern seen in shotgun injuries

questions.text: A 22 years old female was found dead in her house. The following are the images of the dead body on external and internal examination. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Strangulation typically results in markings around the neck, such as bruises or contusions that are often horizontal and can show signs of pressure on the neck tissues. The injury is often caused by a rope, cord, or similar object, and it can lead to asphyxia by restricting airflow and blood flow to the brain Other options: Hanging (A): In hanging, the marks are often vertical, and the cause of death is typically due to mechanical obstruction or hypoxia caused by weight pulling on the neck Drowning (C): Drowning usually causes frothy fluid in the airways and water in the lungs, but external markings around the neck are not as commonly seen Traumatic asphyxia (D): This condition is associated with severe compression of the chest or body, leading to blood congestion and facial cyanosis, but it doesn't typically present with the specific neck marks seen in strangulation

choices.text: Blackening around the wound of entry
Derived from the residue from the barrel of the gun
Gutter fracture of the skull caused by a bullet
Tattooing around the wound of entry

questions.text: What is true about bullet wipe?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bullet wipe refers to the ring of discoloration, often dark in color, around the wound of entry caused by the residue from the bullet itself or the gunpowder that remains on the skin after the bullet passes through. This is different from blackening (which is caused by gunpowder particles directly deposited on the skin) and tattooing (which involves smaller particles from close-range gunshots) Other options: A) Blackening around the wound of entry: This is caused by gunpowder particles deposited on the skin, not bullet wipe C) Gutter fracture of the skull caused by a bullet: This is a result of a high-energy bullet impact but isn't related to bullet wipe D) Tattooing around the wound of entry: This is caused by gunpowder particles and is seen in close-range gunshot wounds, but it is different from bullet wipe

questions.text: identify the plant
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Erythroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. Cocaine is a powerful stimulant and has a significant effect on the central nervous system Other options: A) Hyoscine: Also known as scopolamine, it is derived from plants like Datura and Atropa belladonna and is used for its sedative and anti-motion sickness properties B) Cannabis: This is the plant from which marijuana (cannabis) is derived, containing THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) C) Datura: This plant contains atropine and scopolamine, which are toxic alkaloids used in some medical treatments but can cause poisoning

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Marbling Marbling refers to the greenish-black discoloration of veins and tissues seen in decomposing bodies due to bacterial activity, particularly in the blood vessels. This occurs after death as bacteria break down the tissues, releasing gases that cause this distinctive pattern Other options: Rigor mortis (A): This refers to the postmortem stiffening of the muscles, typically occurring 2-6 hours after death Algor mortis (C): This is the postmortem cooling of the body, as it gradually matches the temperature of the surrounding environment Postmortem lividity (D): This refers to the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body, causing a purplish discoloration, typically occurring within a few hours of death

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rokitansky – in situ: The organs are examined in place (without removal) and then the body is opened for further dissection Other options: Virchow – organ by organ: Each organ is removed and examined individually during the autopsy Ghon’s – en bloc: The organs are removed as a single block or unit, all together, for examination Letulle’s – en masse: The body is opened, and the organs are removed together in one piece, typically after cutting through the chest or abdominal wall

questions.text: An 11 years old girl was found to be quiet and shy in her classroom with intermittent crying since past few days. Later, the Principal has discovered that her uncle was touching her genitals inappropriately. The duty of the Principal is to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The principal must inform the police directly in case of sexual assault or abuse involving minors. According to mandatory reporting laws (such as the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act in India), the principal is obligated to report the incident to law enforcement authorities as soon as they become aware of the abuse Other options: The Child Welfare Committee (CWC) and magistrate may be involved in the subsequent proceedings, the first step is to notify the police. Parents should also be informed, but care should be taken depending on the circumstances to avoid putting the child at risk. The priority is to ensure the child's safety and legal protection

questions.text: Sequentially arrange the following Clauses of 320IPC: 1. Destructionorpermanentimpairingof the powers of any member or joint. 2. Permanent disfiguration of the head or face 3. Emasculation 4. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 3-1-2-4 Emasculation (Option 3): This refers to the permanent loss of masculine sexual function and is listed as the first clause under Section 320 IPC. Since it appears first in the official order, it comes first in the correct sequence. Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint (Option 1): This is listed as the fifth clause in Section 320. It refers to the permanent loss of function in a limb or joint, making it a grievous injury. Permanent disfiguration of the head or face (Option 2): This is the sixth clause. It refers to any injury that leaves a lasting visible mark or deformity on the face or head, which qualifies as grievous hurt. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth (Option 4): This is included under the seventh clause and clearly qualifies as grievous hurt due to the severity and potential functional limitation involved.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Suggilation refers to the discoloration of the skin due to postmortem pooling of blood, commonly seen in the form of bruising or ecchymosis. This occurs when the blood settles in the dependent parts of the body after death, leading to purple or red discoloration Other options: Rigor mortis (A): This refers to the stiffening of the muscles that happens after death, typically beginning 2-6 hours postmortem Algor mortis (B): This refers to the cooling of the body after death, as the body temperature gradually matches the surrounding environment Stiffening (C): This is a synonym for rigor mortis, the process of muscle rigidity after death

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct but reason is not a correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are wrong

questions.text: Assertion: range of shot can be determined by the spread of pellets. Reason: shotgun cartridge contains pellets
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Assertion: The range of a shot can be determined by the spread of pellets. This is true because the spread of the pellets from a shotgun will increase with distance. A close-range shot will have tightly clustered pellets, while a long-range shot will have a wider spread. By assessing how dispersed the pellets are, an investigator can estimate the distance from which the shot was fired Reason: A shotgun cartridge contains pellets. While this is true, it does not directly explain the assertion. The fact that a shotgun cartridge contains pellets is a basic fact about how a shotgun works, but the spread of the pellets at various ranges is what actually helps determine the shot's range. Therefore, the reason is not a correct explanation of the assertion, even though both statements are true

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing cause of death occurs due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon seen in cases of severe hypothermia, where individuals, in an altered mental state due to the cold, may start removing their clothes despite being extremely cold. This happens because of confusion and disorientation caused by the effects of hypothermia on the brain Other options: B) Datura poisoning: While datura can cause delirium and confusion, it does not directly cause paradoxical undressing C) Immersion syndrome: This occurs when a person is immersed in cold water, leading to sudden heart failure or shock, but it is not specifically associated with paradoxical undressing

questions.text: Match the following poisons and tests
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1. Marsh test ? e. Arsenic 2. Silver nitrate test ? b. Aluminium phosphide 3. Cavett test ? d. alcohol 4. Marquis test ? a. Opium

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1-b,2-d,3-e,4-a Paracetamol ? b. N-acetyl cysteineN-acetyl is used as an antidote for paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning Nicotine ? d. Bupropion is sometimes used in smoking cessation and can act as an antagonist to nicotine Morphine ? e. Nalorphine is an opioid antagonist used to counteract the effects of opioid overdose, such as morphine HCN (Hydrogen Cyanide) ? a. Amyl nitrite is used to treat cyanide poisoning by promoting the formation of methemoglobin, which binds cyanide

questions.text: Upto what time if a rape victim complaints, the examination is done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In cases of sexual assault, the medical examination is ideally performed within 72 hours (3 days) to collect critical evidence such as semen, sperm cells, and other biological traces that may be present on the victim's body. The examination is still possible after this time, but the quality of the evidence decreases with time. It's important to note that evidence can still be collected after 3 days, but the chances of finding conclusive material are lower

choices.text: Long term ingestion of arsenic water

questions.text: A 30-year-old person presented to the OPD with the below finding. Which of the following conditions do you see them
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Long-term ingestion of arsenic (typically through contaminated water) can cause chronic arsenic poisoning, which leads to various symptoms, including skin changes such as blackening of the hands, hyperkeratosis, and the formation of lesions. This is a well-known effect of chronic arsenic exposure Other options: A) Chronic Copper sulphate poisoning: Copper poisoning typically results in gastrointestinal symptoms, liver damage, and may cause greenish skin discoloration, but not blackening of the hands C) Application of mercury ointment: Mercury poisoning can cause symptoms like tremors and gingivitis but does not typically result in blackening of the hands D) Application of Calotropis: While Calotropis (also known as madar) contains toxic compounds, it causes dermatitis and blistering rather than blackening of the hands

questions.text: According to Indian medical council act, the hospital records must be returned within
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 72 hours According to the Indian Medical Council Act, hospital records must be returned within 72 hours if requested by the patient or their legal representative, subject to certain conditions. This rule ensures that medical records are made accessible to patients or their families when needed for legal, medical, or personal purposes. The time frame may vary depending on the specific circumstances, but generally, 72 hours is the standard for providing access to medical records

questions.text: Identify the type of injury in the below image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Abrasion An abrasion is a type of injury where the skin is scraped or rubbed off due to friction, often resulting in superficial damage to the epidermis. This is commonly seen in cases of falls or accidents where the skin comes into contact with a rough surface Other options: B) Punctuate bleeding: This refers to small, pinpoint bleeding caused by puncture wounds, typically from a sharp object C) Degloving injury: This is a serious injury where a large section of skin and soft tissue is forcibly separated from the underlying structures, often resulting in extensive tissue damage D) Laceration: A laceration is a deep tear or cut in the skin caused by a blunt object or trauma, resulting in irregular edges

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting, bullet is identified by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Both primary and secondary markings When identifying a bullet, both primary and secondary markings are important • Primary characters refer to the distinctive markings made by the rifling in the barrel of the firearm, such as the land and groove impressions on the bullet • Secondary markings are additional markings that can occur due to the firing pin, ejector, or extractor marks on the bullet or cartridge casing Both of these types of markings, together, help forensic experts identify the type of firearm used and link it to a specific weapon. Therefore, both primary and secondary markings are crucial in bullet fingerprinting for identification

questions.text: Aggressive sexual assault in penetration in POSCO act are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) By threatening Under the POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act), aggressive sexual assault (including penetration) is considered under certain aggravating circumstances. These circumstances include A) By gang: Sexual assault by a group or gang is an aggravating factor B) By police: When a police officer is involved in the assault, it adds to the severity of the offense D) In communal violence: If the assault takes place during communal violence, it is also an aggravating factor However, C) By threatening alone is not considered an aggravating factor in the context of aggressive sexual assault under the POCSO Act. Threatening can be part of the act but doesn't specifically categorize the offense as aggressive sexual assault in the context of penetration

questions.text: Identify the type of base of skull fracture in the below image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hinge fracture A hinge fracture of the base of the skull typically occurs in areas such as the petrous part of the temporal bone. It is characterized by a fracture line that behaves like a hinge or pivot point, where the skull may be displaced in a way that causes limited mobility, like the opening and closing of a hinge. This type of fracture is often associated with significant trauma Other options: A) Ring fracture: A fracture that forms around the foramen magnum, often seen in cases of severe head trauma or high-impact injuries C) Diastatic fracture: A fracture that causes separation of the sutures in the skull, commonly seen in children with developing skulls D) Depressed fracture: This is a type of skull fracture where a portion of the bone is displaced inward, often resulting from direct blunt trauma

questions.text: 18 year old girl was brought to the OPD. On examination she had untorn hymen, flabby labia minora, labia majora separated, fourchette tear present and a roomy vaginal cavity is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The condition described indicates a false virgin status due to the forchette tear, which typically occurs due to previous sexual activity or trauma. The untorn hymen might seem to suggest virginity, but the presence of a forchette tear and other signs like flabby labia minora and roomy vaginal cavity suggest that the individual may have been sexually active before. Hence, she is classified as a false virgin Other options: A) A true virgin: A true virgin would not typically exhibit a forchette tear or other signs of prior sexual activity, and the hymen may or may not be intact C) Pre-menstrual stage: The description does not specifically suggest anything about the menstrual stage or cycle D) Sterile: Sterility refers to the inability to conceive, which cannot be determined from the physical examination provided in this case

questions.text: Which of the following does the below picture correspond to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Suggillation refers to the postmortem pooling of blood in the tissues, commonly observed as bluish discoloration of the skin, usually in the dependent parts of the body. This is commonly seen in cases of death, where gravity causes blood to collect in the lower parts of the body, leading to visible staining. It is also known as postmortem lividity Other options: B) Tattooing: Tattooing occurs when gunpowder or other substances from a firearm are deposited on the skin, causing small punctate lesions around the wound C) Bruise: A bruise is an injury to the skin or underlying tissue, often caused by blunt force trauma, and typically involves the breakage of blood vessels beneath the skin D) Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage refers to active bleeding, either internal or external, due to ruptured blood vessels

questions.text: A female found dead in her bedroom, unlocked room. Investigations later showed her blood value of alcohol 350mg/dl. The image is as shown below. Your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The image shows a large food bolus (indicated by arrows) lodged in the upper airway—likely the pharynx or laryngeal inlet—causing complete obstruction. This is a classic finding in café coronary syndrome. Alcohol level: A blood alcohol level of 350 mg/dL is extremely high and would severely impair the gag reflex and swallowing mechanism. This increases the risk of aspiration or choking. Scene description: Found dead in a locked room suggests no struggle or foul play, supporting a natural cause like sudden choking.

questions.text: Blackfoot disease is associated with which of the following poisons?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B) Arsenic: Associated with blackfoot disease, a severe form of peripheral vascular disease leading to gangrene Other options: A) Cadmium: Causes kidney damage and bone disease, but not blackfoot disease C) Antimony: Toxic, but not linked to blackfoot disease D) Bismuth: Known to cause toxicity with chronic exposure, but not related to blackfoot disease

questions.text: 16 year old rape victim comes to the casualty along with her mother. What is the first step to be taken
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The first step is to take a detailed history from the patient to understand the nature of the case, and this should be done before proceeding with any physical examination or other steps, while ensuring proper consent is obtained A) Start examination and document injuries: This should be done after history and consent is obtained C) Preserve clothing: This is part of the documentation, but it is typically done after detailed history and obtaining consent D) Take consent from mother: Consent is required from the mother or legal guardian, especially as the girl is a minor, before proceeding with any examination or medical procedures, but after detailed history

questions.text: Tactile hallucination of insects crawling on the skin caused by cocaine usage is called as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Formication refers to the tactile hallucination of insects crawling on the skin. It is a common symptom associated with cocaine use, as well as other stimulant drugs or withdrawal states Other options: B) Dipsomania: This refers to an uncontrollable craving for alcohol, often in the form of recurrent binge drinking. It is not related to the sensation of insects crawling on the skin. C) Narcolepsy: This is a neurological disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks. It is unrelated to tactile hallucinations caused by cocaine use D) Erotomania: This is a delusional belief that someone, typically of higher social status, is in love with the person experiencing the delusion. It is not associated with tactile hallucinations like formication

questions.text: As per the guidelines of snakebite management, RIGHT approach is to be used. Which is not included in it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B) Incision: Making an incision (cutting the bite site) is not recommended. This was once a practice, but current guidelines discourage it as it can lead to infection and more tissue damage Other options: A) Reassurance: Reassuring the patient is important in the management of a snakebite, as it helps reduce anxiety and stress, which can exacerbate symptoms. C) Go to hospital: It is critical to transport the victim to a hospital for further treatment, such as the administration of antivenom, if needed D) Tell the doctors your symptoms: It is crucial to inform medical staff about the symptoms, time of bite, and other details to ensure proper treatment

questions.text: A person was brought by the police and had alcohol smell coming from his airways with conjunctival redness. He was able to walk stably and had all motor functions normal. On examination, the opinion of the medical officer is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B) He consumed alcohol but is not under the influence: The person is stable, able to walk normally, and has no signs of impaired motor function, indicating that while alcohol has been consumed, it may not have significantly impaired his abilities at the time of the exam Other options: A) He did not consume alcohol: The presence of alcohol smell from his airways and conjunctival redness suggests alcohol consumption, so this option is incorrect C) He consumed alcohol and is under its influence: There is no evidence of impaired motor function, disorientation, or other signs of being under the influence, so this option is incorrect D) He consumed alcohol, is under its influence and is not a public nuisance: Since he is stable and his motor functions are normal, he is likely not under the influence to the extent that he would be a nuisance

questions.text: A person with firearm injury has only abrasion collar present. Identify the range of the firearm.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Abrasion collar is a ring of abrasions around the wound, often seen in gunshot wounds. It is typically caused by the firearm's muzzle not being in direct contact with the skin, meaning the shot was fired from a distance Distant: This is the range where the injury only has an abrasion collar without significant stippling or burns, indicating that the gunshot was fired from a distance Other options: Close range: Usually associated with gunshot wounds where there is some burning or powder stippling on the skin Near: Involves a bit more distance than close range, but typically still includes stippling and possibly some burns around the wound Contact: Refers to a wound caused by a firearm where the muzzle is in direct contact with the skin, often resulting in powder burns and stippling

questions.text: During autopsy of a case of drowning, which of the following is not confirmative of antemortem findings-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Washerwoman hands (also called wrinkling of the skin) is a postmortem change that occurs when the body has been submerged in water for a prolonged period. It is not confirmative of antemortem drowning and does not necessarily indicate that death occurred due to drowning Other options: Excessive frothing from nose and mouth is a common antemortem sign of drowning, indicating the person was alive during submersion and inhaled water Cadaveric spasm in hand muscles may be seen in drowning victims as a postmortem finding where the body is in a "gripping" position, especially after struggling to hold onto something during the drowning Positive diatom test is an antemortem finding used to help confirm drowning, where diatoms from the water are found in the lungs or other organs of the deceased

choices.text: In case of drowning, postmortem staining is seen in limbs
Greenish discolouration can be seen in subhepatic space
Adipocere can be seen in drowning
Cadaveric spasm is seen in one group of muscles

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect in relation to postmortem findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Postmortem staining is typically seen in the dependent parts of the body after death, where blood settles due to gravity. In cases of drowning, postmortem staining is often seen in the back or posterior parts of the body (depending on how the body is positioned during recovery), but not specifically in the limbs Other options: B) Greenish discoloration in the subhepatic space: This is a postmortem change indicating the beginning of putrefaction, where microbial activity in the body leads to the breakdown of tissue and the formation of gases and discoloration C) Adipocere in drowning: This is a process of conversion of body fat to a wax-like substance during postmortem decomposition, which can occur in drowned bodies, especially in water that is cool or stagnant D) Cadaveric spasm is seen in one group of muscles: This is a postmortem phenomenon where muscles, especially those involved in the final act before death, contract and remain in a fixed position, typically seen in specific muscles, such as those involved in the grasping reflex during drowning

questions.text: A village kid got bit by something and started crying with burning sensation at the bite site. The child was brought to the hospital. His BP-150/90, HR was high, priapism, cold peripheries were present. What should be given next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This case describes symptoms that suggest poisoning from a venomous bite, most likely from scorpion bite that has resulted in systemic effects. The presence of high blood pressure (150/90 mmHg), increased heart rate, priapism, and cold peripheries suggests a sympathetic overactivation, which can occur due to scorpion bite Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker that helps in reducing the sympathetic response, such as high blood pressure and the other associated symptoms like priapism and cold extremities. It helps by blocking the effects of excess catecholamines that cause these symptoms Other options: B) Atropine: This is an anticholinergic used for bradycardia or to reverse the effects of organophosphorus poisoning. It wouldn't be appropriate here as the issue is likely related to sympathetic overactivation rather than parasympathetic effects C) Adrenaline can be used for anaphylaxis or severe allergic reactions, it would not be the first choice in this case of sympathetic overactivity, as it may worsen the high blood pressure and other symptoms D) Antisnake venom: If a snake bite was confirmed and the symptoms were related to snake venom, antivenom would be necessary. However, based on the described symptoms (high blood pressure, priapism, cold peripheries), the immediate concern is controlling sympathetic overactivation with prazosin

questions.text: A patient in a coma is admitted in the ICU. He is given injection morphine. After he wakes from coma, he is again given morphine for pain relief. Since then, he presents with respiratory depression. Drug to be given must be-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Naloxone Morphine is a narcotic analgesic that acts on the central nervous system to relieve pain. Side effects of morphine are: Respiratory depression, Pinpoint pupils, Constipation, mental and physical dependence. Naloxone is an antagonist at morphine receptors, hence used in morphine poisoning.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed white colour rodenticide powder and presents with K+ levels as 2.5 meq. On examination irregular pulse present with muscle paralysis, ECG showed multiple ventricular ectopic. Suspected poison is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Barium carbonate Barium salts are white colour rodenticide powder are also used in a number of industries, including mining, ceramics, plastics, and adhesives and as a green coloring in fireworks. It is also a rodenticide. In poisoning, it blocks passive efflux potassium channels without affecting the Na/K- ATPase pump resulting in an increase in intracellular potassium and extracellular hypokalemia. Barium poisoning is accompanied by severe hypokalemia, and potassium infusion is often an effective antidote. If administered promptly, soluble sulfates are also an effective antidote.

questions.text: What is the antidote for cyanide toxicity A. Amyl nitrite B. Sodium nitrite C. Sodium thiosulfate D. Glyceryl trinitrite
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) a,b,c Amyl nitrite, Sodium nitrite, Sodium thiosulfate is used for cyanide poisoning. Administer cyanide antidote when cyanide poisoning is clinically suspected. Hydroxocobalamin is the preferred antidote. If hydroxocobalamin is available, give the following: • Hydroxocobalamin 5 g (adults) or 70 mg/kg IV (pediatric patients, maximum 5 g) • If hydroxocobalamin is not available, cyanide toxicity is known or strongly suspected in an adult patient, and there are no contraindications to nitrites, give the following: • Sodium nitrite (3% solution) 10 mL IV (300 mg) at 2.5 to 5 mL per minute; may repeat once • Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) 50 mL IV (12.5 g) immediately following sodium nitrite administration; may ) repeat once • If hydroxocobalamin is not available and cyanide toxicity is possible but not certain in an adult patient, or the patient has contraindications to nitrites, give the following: • Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) 50 mL IV (12.5 g); may repeat once

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Korsakoff's psychosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ophthalmoplegia Korsakoff psychosis is a late complication of persistent Wernicke encephalopathy and results in memory deficits, confusion, and behavioral changes.

questions.text: A patient presents with paresthesia, tetany, muscle twitching, muscular cramps with urinary crystals as shown in the image. They are typical symptoms of poisoning with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ethylene glycol In cases of ethylene glycol poisoning, calcium oxalate may be excreted not only as dihydrate crystals, but also as monohydrate crystals. In ethylene glycol poisoning is suspected, begin antidotal therapy empirically while awaiting confirmation. Antidotes are fomepizole and ethanol. B-vitamin therapy may be used as an adjunct to antidotal therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about heat exhaustion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Loss of thermoregulatory mechanism A. Loss of thermoregulatory mechanism Incorrect ? In heat exhaustion, thermoregulation is still intact. Loss of this mechanism is a feature of heat stroke, not heat exhaustion. B. Orthostatic hypotension is seen Correct ? Due to dehydration and peripheral vasodilation, orthostatic hypotension is common. C. Altered consciousness is not seen Correct ? Patients are usually alert, although they may feel weak, dizzy, or fatigued. Significant altered consciousness occurs in heat stroke. D. Core body temperature is < 105°C Correct ? Core body temp in heat exhaustion is usually between 37°C and 40°C, not exceeding 40.5°C (or ~105°F). So this statement, while awkwardly worded, is factually correct.
